verses.text: Many people have tried to put together an account of what happened among us—the events passed down by those who saw everything from the beginning and became messengers of the word.

footnotes.content: The Greek word αὐτόπται (autoptai) is a technical term for firsthand observers—the root of our word "autopsy" (seeing for oneself). Luke emphasizes: his sources were people who were there.

verses.text: So I decided, after looking carefully into it all from the start, to write it out for you in order, most excellent Theophilus, so you can know for certain what you've been taught.

footnotes.content: Either a real name (Greek: "lover of God") or a symbolic title for all readers. "Most excellent" (κράτιστε) was a title for Roman officials. Ancient books required wealthy patrons for copying and distribution.

sections.heading: An Old Priest, an Empty Nursery

verses.text: Back when Herod was king of Judea, there was a priest named Zechariah. He belonged to the priestly division of Abijah—one of 24 groups that took turns serving in the temple. His wife Elizabeth was also from a priestly family—a daughter of Aaron.

footnotes.content: Herod the Great (ruled c. 37–4 BCE) was a Roman-appointed king, known for monumental building projects (Temple expansion) and brutal cruelty. His mention is also theological irony—this tyrant's days are numbered, for the true king is coming.
About 18,000 priests existed, divided into 24 groups that each served two weeks per year (1 Chronicles 24:7-18). Abijah was the eighth division.

verses.text: Both of them lived the kind of life God approved of, following all the Lord's commands and regulations without fault.
But they had no children. Elizabeth couldn't conceive, and now they were both old.

footnotes.content: In the ancient world, childlessness wasn't just private sorrow—it was social catastrophe: no support in old age, no inheritance, and many assumed divine punishment. That Zechariah stayed with Elizabeth (divorce would have been allowed) shows deep love. Luke immediately clarifies: they were "righteous before God"—their childlessness was NOT punishment.

verses.text: One day, when Zechariah's division was on duty, he was serving as priest before God. Following the custom of the priesthood, he was chosen by lot to enter the Lord's sanctuary and burn incense—a once-in-a-lifetime honor for most priests.

footnotes.content: The incense offering occurred twice daily (morning and evening sacrifice) on a special altar inside the sanctuary (the holy space before the Most Holy Place). With 18,000 priests, an individual might receive this honor only once in his lifetime—if ever. Zechariah enters the space alone.

verses.text: The whole crowd of people was outside praying at the hour of the incense offering.
Then an angel of the Lord appeared to him, standing to the right of the incense altar—the position of honor.

footnotes.content: In ancient culture, the right side was the position of honor and blessing. The angel appears at the most dignified position.

verses.text: When Zechariah saw him, he was terrified. Fear overwhelmed him.

But the angel said to him: "Don't be afraid, Zechariah. Your prayer has been heard. Your wife Elizabeth will have a son, and you are to name him John. He will bring you joy and delight, and many will celebrate his birth,

footnotes.content: The most frequent command in the Bible. Fear is a universal human experience—whether of the unknown, of change, or of the sacred. The biblical invitation isn't "Suppress your fear," but "Fear doesn't have to have the last word." Psychologically, this corresponds to the distinction between the feeling (normal) and our response to it (shapeable).
Greek Ἰωάννης (Iōannēs), from Hebrew יוֹחָנָן (Yochanan): "YHWH has shown grace." The name itself proclaims God's gracious action.

verses.text: because he will be great in the Lord's sight.
Zechariah said to the angel, "How can I be sure of this? I'm an old man, and my wife is well along in years."

The angel answered, "I am Gabriel. I stand in God's presence. I was sent to speak to you and tell you this good news. But now—because you did not believe my words, which will come true at the proper time—you will be silent. Unable to speak until the day this happens."

footnotes.content: One of only two angels named in the Hebrew Bible (alongside Michael). Gabriel appears in Daniel 8-9 as a messenger of divine revelations. "I stand in God's presence" indicates the highest angelic rank.

verses.text: Meanwhile, the people were waiting for Zechariah, wondering why he was taking so long in the sanctuary. When he came out, he couldn't speak to them. They realized he had seen a vision inside. He kept making signs to them but remained unable to speak.
When his time of service was over, he went home. After this, his wife Elizabeth became pregnant. She stayed in seclusion for five months, saying,
"The Lord has done this for me. He looked on me with favor. He has taken away my disgrace among the people."

footnotes.content: Elizabeth openly names what the culture assumed: childlessness as "disgrace." Her words aren't self-pity but testimony to liberation. God sees people whom society overlooks or devalues—and acts.

verses.text: In the sixth month of Elizabeth's pregnancy, God sent the angel Gabriel to a town in Galilee called Nazareth—a place so small and insignificant that nobody knew it—to a virgin engaged to a man named Joseph, who was descended from David's royal line. The virgin's name was Mary.

footnotes.content: A tiny village (500-2000 inhabitants) of no significance—not mentioned in the Hebrew Bible, Josephus, or the Talmud. Archaeological finds show simple agricultural workers. The contrast with royal promises is deliberate irony.

Jewish engagement (אירוסין/erusin) was a legally binding contract, usually arranged by families. It lasted about a year. Sexual relations were forbidden; pregnancy during engagement was considered adultery—potentially a capital crime (Deuteronomy 22:23-24). Mary is taking an enormous risk.

verses.text: The angel came to her and said, "Greetings! You are highly favored. The Lord is with you."

footnotes.content: Greek κεχαριτωμένη (kecharitōmenē)—a perfect passive participle: "one who has been graced/favored." Not "full of grace" (like the Latin Vulgate: gratia plena), but: God has acted, Mary has received. The focus is on God's initiative, not Mary's inherent quality.

verses.text: Mary was deeply troubled by these words and wondered what kind of greeting this could be.

But the angel said to her, "Don't be afraid, Mary. You have found favor with God. You will conceive and give birth to a son, and you are to name him Jesus. He will be great. He will be called the Son of the Most High. The Lord God will give him the throne of his ancestor David, and he will reign over Jacob's descendants forever. His kingdom will never end."

footnotes.content: Greek Ἰησοῦς (Iēsous), from Hebrew יְהוֹשֻׁעַ (Yeshua/Joshua): "YHWH saves" or "YHWH is salvation." The name is his mission.
Reference to the Nathan prophecy (2 Samuel 7:12-16): God promised David a descendant whose kingdom would last "forever." This messianic hope shaped centuries of Jewish expectation.

verses.text: "How can this be?" Mary asked the angel. "I have not been with a man."

The angel answered, "The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you—the same word used for God's presence filling the tabernacle. So the holy one to be born will be called the Son of God.

footnotes.content: Greek ἐπισκιάσει (episkiasei)—the same verb describes how God's glory "overshadowed" the tabernacle in Exodus 40:35. The language evokes divine presence and protection, NOT physical conception (as in Greek myths of Zeus and mortal women). Mary becomes a new "tent of meeting" where God dwells.

The virgin birth is a mystery of faith that Christians understand differently. For some it is literally historical; for others symbolic (emphasizing divine initiative). All Christians agree: Jesus comes from God. Luke deliberately emphasizes: this is not divine procreation as in pagan myths, but the creative work of the Spirit.

verses.text: "And here's more: Your relative Elizabeth—even she has conceived a son in her old age. She who was called barren is now in her sixth month. For nothing is impossible with God."

"I am God's servant," Mary answered. "Let it be with me as you have said."

Then the angel left her.

footnotes.content: Greek δούλη κυρίου (doulē kyriou)—literally "slave of the Lord." Mary uses the strongest term of submission. Yet in biblical tradition, "servant/slave of God" is an honor title: Abraham, Moses, David, the prophets are called this. Mary joins this lineage. Her "yes" is active consent, not passive resignation.

"Let it be with me as you have said"—these words became known in Christian tradition as the "Fiat" (Latin: "let it be done"). They describe an attitude of radical openness to the unexpected. Psychologically, the opposite of control isn't passivity but active surrender—choosing to engage with something larger than ourselves that we don't fully understand. We face similar moments in life: an unexpected offer, a diagnosis, a new relationship. The question isn't whether life brings surprises, but how we meet them.

verses.text: In those days Mary got ready and hurried to a town in the hill country of Judea—a journey of three to five days. She entered Zechariah's home and greeted Elizabeth.

footnotes.content: From Nazareth to the Judean hill country is about 80-100 kilometers. A young woman traveling alone was unusual and risky (bandits, propriety concerns). Mary likely traveled with a caravan or family group.

verses.text: When Elizabeth heard Mary's greeting, the baby leaped in her womb, and Elizabeth was filled with the Holy Spirit. She cried out in a loud voice:"Blessed are you among women,and blessed is the fruit of your womb!

lines.text: "Blessed are you among women,
and blessed is the fruit of your womb!

verses.text: But why am I so honored, that the mother of my Lord should come to me? As soon as I heard your greeting, the baby in my womb leaped for joy.

footnotes.content: Elizabeth calls Mary the mother of her κύριος (kyrios)—"Lord." In the Greek translation of the Old Testament (Septuagint), κύριος translates the divine name YHWH. Elizabeth thus implicitly recognizes the divine status of Mary's unborn child. This is the first human confession about Jesus—and it comes from a woman.

verses.text: You are blessed because you believed that what the Lord said to you would come true."

footnotes.content: Greek μακαρία (makaria)—often translated "blessed" but meaning: happy, fortunate, to be envied. Elizabeth contrasts Mary's faith with Zechariah's doubt: Mary believed—and that makes her enviable.

verses.text: And Mary said:"Everything in me celebrates God—my spirit bursts with joybecause of God, my rescuer.

lines.text: And Mary said:
"Everything in me celebrates God—
my spirit bursts with joy
because of God, my rescuer.

verses.text: He looked at the nobody that I am,at his servant in her low place.And from now on,all generations will call me blessed,

footnotes.content: Greek ταπείνωσις (tapeinōsis) means low social status, NOT humility as a virtue (that would be ταπεινοφροσύνη). Mary describes her social position: young, female, poor, from a village nobody knows. God looks at those whom the world overlooks.

lines.text: He looked at the nobody that I am,
at his servant in her low place.
And from now on,
all generations will call me blessed,

verses.text: because the Mighty One has done great things for me.Holy is his name.

lines.text: because the Mighty One has done great things for me.
Holy is his name.

verses.text: His mercy extends to those who honor him,from generation to generation.

lines.text: His mercy extends to those who honor him,
from generation to generation.

verses.text: He has shown the strength of his arm;he has scattered those who are arrogantin the thoughts of their hearts.

lines.text: He has shown the strength of his arm;
he has scattered those who are arrogant
in the thoughts of their hearts.

verses.text: He has pulled down rulers from their thronesand lifted up the humble.

lines.text: He has pulled down rulers from their thrones
and lifted up the humble.

verses.text: He has filled the hungry with good thingsand sent the rich away empty.

footnotes.content: The Magnificat has been called "the most revolutionary document in the world." A peasant teenager proclaims the overthrow of the powerful and the elevation of the powerless. This "great reversal" runs through Luke's entire Gospel (6:20-26; 14:11; 16:19-31). In the 1980s, Latin American military governments banned public reading of the Magnificat.

The Magnificat continues to inspire liberation theology: God stands with the poor and oppressed. It also warns against spiritualizing: Luke means not just inner attitudes but concrete social and economic transformation. What does this mean for our attitude toward wealth and power?

lines.text: He has filled the hungry with good things
and sent the rich away empty.

verses.text: He has helped his servant Israel,remembering his mercy—just as he promised our ancestors,to Abraham and his descendants forever."

lines.text: He has helped his servant Israel,
remembering his mercy—
just as he promised our ancestors,
to Abraham and his descendants forever."

verses.text: Mary stayed with Elizabeth about three months and then returned home.
When the time came for Elizabeth to have her baby, she gave birth to a son. Her neighbors and relatives heard that the Lord had shown her great mercy, and they celebrated with her.
On the eighth day, as required by Jewish law, they came to circumcise the child, and they were going to name him Zechariah after his father.

footnotes.content: Circumcision on the eighth day (Leviticus 12:3) was the covenant sign given to Abraham and his descendants (Genesis 17). It marked belonging to Israel. The naming was a community event: neighbors and relatives gathered.

verses.text: But his mother spoke up. "No!" she said. "He is to be called John."
They said to her, "None of your relatives has that name."

Then they made signs to his father, asking what he wanted to name the child. He asked for a writing tablet and wrote: "His name is John."

Everyone was amazed.

Immediately his mouth was opened and his tongue set free, and he began to speak, praising God. Fear came on all their neighbors, and throughout the hill country of Judea, people were talking about all these things.

Everyone who heard about it wondered, asking, "What then will this child become?"

For the Lord's hand was with him.
His father Zechariah was filled with the Holy Spirit and prophesied:
"Praise the Lord, the God of Israel!He has come to his people and set them free.

footnotes.content: Hebrew בָּרוּךְ (baruch), Greek Εὐλογητός (Eulogētos)—the classic opening of Jewish praise prayers (berachot). Not "May God be blessed," but "God is worthy of praise."

lines.text: "Praise the Lord, the God of Israel!
He has come to his people and set them free.

verses.text: He has raised up a powerful rescuer for usin the house of his servant David—

footnotes.content: Literally: κέρας σωτηρίας (keras sōtērias)—"horn of salvation." The animal horn was a symbol of power and strength (cf. Psalm 18:2). The metaphor is obscure in English, hence the sense-translation.

lines.text: He has raised up a powerful rescuer for us
in the house of his servant David—

verses.text: just as he promised long agothrough his holy prophets—rescue from our enemiesand from the hand of all who hate us,

lines.text: just as he promised long ago
through his holy prophets—
rescue from our enemies
and from the hand of all who hate us,

verses.text: to show mercy to our ancestorsand to remember his holy covenant,the oath he swore to our father Abraham:

footnotes.content: Greek διαθήκη (diathēkē)—God's binding commitment. The oath to Abraham (Genesis 22:16-18) promised: descendants, land, blessing for all nations. Zechariah sees these ancient promises now being fulfilled.

lines.text: to show mercy to our ancestors
and to remember his holy covenant,
the oath he swore to our father Abraham:

verses.text: to rescue us from the hand of our enemiesand enable us to serve him without fear,in holiness and righteousness before himall our days.

lines.text: to rescue us from the hand of our enemies

all our days.

verses.text: And you, my child, will be calleda prophet of the Most High;for you will go before the Lordto prepare the way for him,

footnotes.content: Reference to Isaiah 40:3: "A voice cries out: Prepare the way of the LORD in the wilderness!" John will fulfill this role—the voice in the wilderness.

lines.text: And you, my child, will be called
a prophet of the Most High;
for you will go before the Lord
to prepare the way for him,

verses.text: to give his people the knowledge of rescuethrough the forgiveness of their sins,

footnotes.content: The word "rescue" (σωτηρία, sōtēria) means comprehensive liberation in biblical context—not just in a religious sense, but from everything that constrains life. The Bible uses various images: liberation from slavery (Exodus), restoration of honor and dignity (especially important in shame cultures), healing from illness, victory over hostile powers. In Western Christianity, often only the legal image was emphasized ("debt paid"). The forgiveness Zechariah speaks of is broader: it enables a new beginning in all dimensions of life.

lines.text: to give his people the knowledge of rescue
through the forgiveness of their sins,

verses.text: because of the gut-deep mercy of our God,by which the rising sun will come to us from heaven

footnotes.content: Greek σπλάγχνα ἐλέους (splanchna eleous)—literally "bowels of mercy." Ancient people located deep emotions in the internal organs. God's mercy is not abstract but visceral, embodied, from the gut.

Greek ἀνατολὴ ἐξ ὕψους (anatolē ex hypsous) has double meaning: (1) sunrise/dawn and (2) the messianic "Branch" (Jeremiah 23:5; Zechariah 3:8; 6:12 use similar terms). Zechariah deliberately plays on both meanings.

lines.text: because of the gut-deep mercy of our God,
by which the rising sun will come to us from heaven

verses.text: to shine on those living in darknessand in the shadow of death,to guide our feet into the path of peace."

footnotes.content: Echo of Psalm 23:4 ("valley of the shadow of death") and Isaiah 9:2 ("The people walking in darkness have seen a great light"). The imagery of darkness and light runs through the entire Bible.

lines.text: to shine on those living in darkness
and in the shadow of death,
to guide our feet into the path of peace."

verses.text: The child grew and became strong in spirit. He lived in the wilderness until the day he appeared publicly to Israel.

footnotes.content: The Judean wilderness between Jerusalem and the Dead Sea was home to various groups seeking purity—including possibly the Essenes (Qumran community). Whether John had contact with them is debated. Theologically, the wilderness is a place of preparation, testing, and new beginnings.
